716922f-a.text:
100 Broad Street, west side, at the intersection of Bridge and Broad Streets. Also shown is Bridge Street, north side, west from Broad, to, but Mnot including Whitehall Street. Building shown is occupied by the Bush Terminal Buildings Co.

716923f-a.text:
100-90 Broad Street, west side, from Pearl to Stone Streets. The small building at the left is the Bush Terminal Building. The block from Bridge to Stone Streets will soon be demolished for the Stone & Webster Building. I1 the left background is the tower of the Produce Exchange (1885), and the 50 Broadway Building.
April 1, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
716923f-a.folder: Broad Street & Pearl Street, Manhattan, NY

716921f-a.text:
98-68 Broad Street, west side, from Bridge to Beaver Streets, inclusive, also showing 11-21 Stone Street, west of, adjoining, and at the N.W. corner of Broad Street. The Stone &: Webster Building will rise on the clearing in the foreground. The three-story building on the N.W. corner of Stone Street has replaced a five-story building. The next four buildings, the last of which is the Maritime Exchange, will be demolished for the Maritime Exchange Building.
September 20, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
716921f-a.folder: Broad Street & Bridge Street, Manhattan, NY

716917f-a.text:
An aerial view of 97-105 Broad Street, east side, from Pearl to Water Streets, with the East River and part of the Brooklyn skyline in the background. Iu the centre is Fraunces' Tavern, a famous eighteenth century inn; it was here that Washington said farewell to the officers of the Continental army, before going into what he expected to be pernmanent retirement at Mount Vernon.
August 28, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
716917f-a.folder: Broad Street & Pearl Street, Manhattan, NY

722482f-a.text:
50 to 36 Pearl Street, south side, west from and including Broad (left), to but not including Moore Streets, showing the 16-story building of the New York Telephone Co. (Nos. 50-42). In the foreground are shown the roof tops of four 4-story units of the Bush Terminal Co., extending. triangularly, westward from Broad Street on Pearl and Bridge Streets. In the background is visible a portion of the East River and the Brooklyn
shore.
August 28, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
722482f-a.folder: Pearl Street & Broad Street, Manhattan, NY

716919f-a.text:
98-96 Broad Street, west side, from, but not including, Bridge Street, to and including Stone Street. The buildings in the foreground will soon be replaced by the 24-story Stone & Webster Building. No. 88, at the N.W. corner of Stone Street, has just been demolished,
and will be replaced by a three-story building.
June 20, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
716919f-a.folder: Broad Street & Bridge Street, Manhattan, NY

716920f-b.text:
(1)
98-92 Broad Street, at, adjoining, and north of the N.W. corner of Bridge Street. In the background is the tower of the Produce
Exchange.
June 20, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, also showing the Bush Terminal Company at the left. The buildings shown in No. 1 have been demolished and work has begun on the 24-story Stone & Webster Building, which will occupy the block from Bridge to Stone Streets. At the right, the 36-story
Maritime Exchange Building is about half finished.
October 3, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

722484f-a.text:
Pearl Street, at the S. S. corner of Broad Street (right), showing Fraunces Tavern after reconstruction by the Sons of the Revolution in 1905-7. Note the absence of the flag pole on the Pearl Street side over the entrance.
1913
H. N. Tiemann, photo
Gift ot Urbrock Collection
722484f-a.folder: Pearl Street & Broad Street, Manhattan, NY

722485f.text:
Pearl Street, at the S. E. corner of Broad Street, showing Praunces Tavern.. This structure was originally the homestead of Etienne DeLancey and was erected in 1730. He sold same to Samuel Fraunces in 1762, for a tavern, the "Cueen Catherine". The Chamber of Commerce held meetings here. It was Washington's Headcuarters and it was from here that he bede farewell to the officers of his Continental Army in 1783. Samuel Fraunces sold it in 1785. The Sons of the Revolution purchased it in 1905 and restored itto the present appearance. Note the tablet on the Broad Street side
refering to this act.
About 1915
B. Hellmich, photo
82 2. Broadway, N. Y. C.
Gift of Crbrock Collection
722485f.folder: Pearl Street & Broad Street, Manhattan, NY
